title: 107_hr3922
content: The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" aims to prevent corporate expatriation to avoid US income tax. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" addresses corporate expatriation to avoid US income tax by defining the term 'domestic' for corporations and partnerships under the Internal Revenue Code. It states that a corporation or partnership is considered domestic if created or organized in the United States or under its laws, unless specified otherwise by the Secretary in regulations. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation is treated as a domestic corporation. The acquiring corporation in a corporate expatriation transaction is treated as a domestic corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, a nominally foreign acquiring corporation obtains substantially all properties of a domestic corporation, with over 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation. Lower stock ownership requirements apply to nominally foreign corporations with limited business activities. In corporate expatriation transactions, lower stock ownership requirements apply to nominally foreign corporations with limited business activities, where the stock is publicly traded in the US. The term 'corporate expatriation transaction' includes transactions where a nominally foreign acquiring corporation acquires properties constituting a trade or business of a domestic entity, provided the stock is publicly traded in the US. The acquiring corporation must hold more than 80 percent of the stock after acquiring properties from a domestic partnership. The acquiring corporation must hold over 80% of the stock after acquiring properties from a domestic partnership, with special rules for related transactions. Special rules apply for related transactions and ownership determination in the context of acquiring properties from a domestic partnership. The term 'nominally foreign corporation' is defined within this framework. The term 'nominally foreign corporation' is defined as any corporation that would be treated as a foreign corporation, and the 'expanded affiliated group' is defined as an affiliated group without certain restrictions. The term 'expanded affiliated group' refers to an affiliated group without specific restrictions. The Secretary of the Treasury will adjust tax rates to offset revenue changes resulting from amendments to the corporate tax code. The amendment made by this section will result in a net decrease in revenues for a taxable year equal to the net increase in revenue for that year. Tax rates will be determined based on estimates by the Secretary of the Treasury, with adjustments made for succeeding years. The amendment applies to corporate expatriation transactions completed after September 11, 2001. The amendment applies to corporate expatriation transactions completed after September 11, 2001, with a special rule for transactions completed on or before that date.
